title: Can I just declare bankruptcy on a medical bill.I do not have any balance on my credit cards accounts.my credit is very good.
question: The medical bill I was just informed last month that I have a balance of over 48K.they said the insurance did not cover for been out of network. In 2016 I was in dyalisis used to live in Nevada. we request service in California and the arrangements were made with the same company I was receiving the dialysis.I'm out of dialysis. Insurance pay them what they pay in network.They are now sending me the bill of balance.I make an appeal and waiting for decision.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy exemptions,Credit repair,Credit score,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Appeals
answers: Bankruptcy might be one option, but it may not be your only option. Medical debt is remarkably easy to settle at a substantial discount and to file any form of bankruptcy, you need to meet a number of eligibility requirements. If you do go with bankruptcy, be aware that in most instances, your credit score will drop significantly. Hope this perspective helps!

You must list any and all debts in any bankruptcy. No exceptions ever. But we dont know why you say a ch 13 as you may in fact file a ch 7 if you qualify and be done in 3 months instead of 3 years! Good luckl,

Mr. Kaplan and Mr. Salanick gave you good answers. I would add a couple of points.

I often have clients tell me that they have good credit. When we check their credit score, it is very low. So the only way to find out if you credit score is really good (700 or above), is to find out what each of the 3 credit bureau -has for your score. BTW, CreditKarma.Com is free, but the score that CreditKarma says you haves is usually 30 to 50 points higher than your scores with Experian, Equifax and Trans Union.

As stated, you must list all the creditors that you owe money to on the date you file your case. You also need to know that most national lenders and some local lenders purchase a weekly download from one of the three credit bureaus and a company call Aacer.. The credit card banks that do this have software that matches the last week's filings with the banks' accounts, and most of them cancel the cards even though their customer owes nothing on the card.

That does not mean that you should not file. I have clients that follow our advise and have a credit score back up over 700 between 2 and 3 years after the discharge. That does not happen magically, you must work at it. If your attorney does not give you any help with rebuilding your credit after bankruptcy just Google credit repair and how to rebuild my credit after bankruptcy.

I’m not sure that I was able to read and understand your entire question. It appears that it may have been cut short towards the end.

Having understood the first portion of your question: It appears that you you are struggling with substantial debt which consists solely of accumulated medical bills, not covered by your health insurance.

You have asked whether or not you can file for bankruptcy in order to relieve yourself from this medical debt, despite the fact that have no other debts?

In response, there is a preliminary question that must be answered as to whether or not you are eligible to file for bankruptcy and receive a discharge, and if you are eligible, it must then be determined whether of not the benefits of filing bankruptcy are going to outweigh any potential burdens that may accompany a bankruptcy filing in your particular instance.

Given the large number of facts that must be reviewed in order to make this determination, the best way to get this accomplished Would be for you to arrange an initial consultation with a qualified bankruptcy Attorney.

In the event that you are eligible for filing under Chapter 7 or chapter 13, the fact that you do not have any other bills, aside from the medical bills will not be a problem. However, keep in mind that when you file for bankruptcy, you must list “all“ of your creditors. A “Creditor “ by definition, includes any person, company, or entity of any kind that you owe money to at the time of filing.

The point here is that you do not get to pick and choose which creditors are going to be listed.

All creditors must be included within the bankruptcy schedules, regardless of how small the balances are, or how well you may be keeping up with the payments etc.

Keeping the above definition in mind, are you still sure that you don’t have any other creditors?
If you don’t, that’s fine, but if you do, you should understand that they will have to be listed and included within your bankruptcy.

You stated that you presently have good credit. Clearly, a bankruptcy filing will have a detrimental effect upon your credit and it will take a while to rebuild it.

Whether or not the benefits of getting rid of the debt are worth the burden of having to rebuild your credit is a decision that you may want to weigh carefully before moving forward with a bankruptcy filing.

I hope this Informational is helpful to you.

Yes you can file bankruptcy regardless if you have any amount of credit card debt, or if you only have the medical debt you describe. There is no minimum amount of debt required for you to file for bankruptcy protection and relief. Likewise, the Bankruptcy Code has no requirement that you have credit card debt, or any (other) certain type of debt, to be eligible to file bankruptcy.

The only caveat here is that you must include all creditors of any amount when your bankruptcy case is filed; you are not permitted to “pick and choose” among the creditors/debt that will be included in your bankruptcy case.
